Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Exploiting Void Symmetries to Control the Self-Assembly of Nanoparticles

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Kumar, Sanat / Panagiotopoulos, Athanassios
Proposal Number: 1403049 / 1402166
Institution: Columbia University / Princeton University
Title: Collaborative Research: Exploiting Void Symmetries to Control the Self-Assembly of Nanoparticles

The assembly of nanoparticles (NPs) into colloidal crystals is a promising way to obtain ordered nanocomposite materials with unique properties determined by the choice of the constituent NPs. If successful, this novel approach will have a significant impact on the ability of experimentalists to rationally design ordered colloidal crystals for a wide range of optical and catalytic applications, such as photonic crystals, optical switches and filters, and catalytic devices. The PIs have shown a novel way to selectively stabilize one crystal structure over another possible one by the use of polymers that can intercalate between the NPS.

The PIs have made an interesting discovery that, even when the energy, pressure, and packing fraction for two crystal isomorphs, e.g., HCP and FCC, are the same, the distribution of voids within the crystals are different. By filling the voids with polymers of different length, they were able to show that one can selectively stabilize HCP over FCC crystals. Based on these findings, they propose to make use of this novel insight about void symmetries and size-distributions to select a desired polymorph from a suite of competing crystal structure. In this proposal, they will use molecular dynamics (using Graphics Processing Unit (GPU)-based molecular dynamics simulations) and Monte-Carlo methods to study the colloidal crystals in colloid/polymer blends, . They will explore several structures of spherically symmetric and patchy particles with polymers of varying conformation and flexibility in order to understand how to maximize the polymers' entropy in voids of different geometries, and how the introduction of enthalpic interactions may act in counterbalance to the polymer entropy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project was to develop methods to stabilize desired crystal morphologies from a suite of competing structures which have similar free energies (e.g., face centered cubic versus body centered cubic; diamond versus tetrastack hard sphere morphologies). One key idea underlying our work was the simple concept that void size distributions in colloid crystals play a central role in determining the thermodynamics of polymer/nanoparticle mixtures. Thus, we explored the use polymer additives that have different free energies in the competing morphologies to direct crystallization. We also explored the effects of solvent evaporation and particle architecture on the quality of the crystal phases obtained. 

The project has developed methodologies of leveraging patch architecture and disparities in void size distributions that can be used to select a desired polymorph from a suite of competing crystal structures, and derive the design principles that are necessary to achieve this goal. In addition, the project has produced general machine-learning methods for automated crystal structure identification. 

Overall, the project has resulted in 12 peer-reviewed publications over its 4-year duretion. It has provided the basis for many invited seminars and lectures, and contributed presentations at scientific meetings. 

In terms of broader impacts, there is significant practical interest in obtaining colloidal crystals with well-defined global order for applications in a range of optical and catalytic devices, for example photonic crystals, optical filters and switches and chemical sensors. Reversible grafted nanoparticle transitions in solvent-free conditions may offer new ways to control the self-assembly of nanoparticles at experimentally accessible conditions. Methods for automated crystal structure identification developed in this project could find application in many fields, including photonics, energy conversion, and biosensing.
